title-group.article-title: Sacrificial Memory and Political Legitimacy in Postwar Italy:Reliving and Remembering World War II

abstract.p: This article examines the formative role of the World War II experience in shaping politically relevant memories in postwar Italy. Rather than considering the past a legacy or a heritage—something abstract, malleable and susceptible to serving political interests—the focus here is on the meaning-giving power of memories and symbols in the historical evolution. The birth of Italian democracy after the war was preceded by disruptive events that could have divided the nation. This article illustrates how contested and fragmented interpretations of critical events were structured by and through the dimension of cultural memory, which sustained social and political imaginations, eventually shaping characters and outcomes of the Italian political transformation.

The bodies of the partisans were put on display as a warning to local residents lest they consider joining the Resistance. On April 29, 1945, the bodies of Benito Mussolini, his mistress Claretta Petacci, and twelve fascists were taken to the same square and hung upside down on meat-hooks from the roof of a gas station, then stoned by civilians from below. This was not a deliberate act of humiliation of the bodies. Quite the opposite, such a highly symbolic “spectacle” provided both confirmation of Mussolini's demise—thereby discouraging the fascists from continuing the fight—and revenge for the hanging of many partisans in the same place by Axis authorities.

“Radical stupidity”—a form of spiritual decline and the failure to achieve humanity—is the central explanation Eric Voegelin offers for Hitler's accession to and remaining in power. See Eric Voegelin , The Collected Works , vol.31, Hitler and the Germans , ed. Detlev Clemens and Brendan Purcell (:University of Missouri Press,1999),87–88,96. It is interesting to see how closely Hannah Arendt's notion of “thoughtlessness” inThe Life of the Mindcorresponds to Voegelin's diagnosis of the collapse of spirit underlying National Socialism as ideology: “There was no sign in him [Eichmann] of firm ideological convictions or of specific evil motives, and the only notable characteristic one could detect in his past behavior during the trial … was something entirely negative: it was not stupidity but thoughtlessness”; Hannah Arendt , The Life of the Mind (:Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich,1978),4–6. Furthermore, the word “stupidity” hints at Primo Levi's well-known statement about the 1938 Italian racial laws, which were, he said in 1975, “decisive for me, as well as for many others; they were the demonstration by their absurdity of the stupidity of Fascism.
